distortionDetails.name: Catastrophizing
distortionDetails.subtitle: What if the worst happens?
distortionDetails.description: You to expect the worst-case-scenario in any situation. You often find yourself thinking, 'What ifâ€¦?'. You may feel like something is unbearable or impossible, even if it isn't.
distortionDetails.example: Example: You recieve some constructive cristicism, or correcting feedback at work. A person who catastrophizes may think, 'I am going to get fired, and then I am not going to be able to pay my bills, and I'll lose my house, etc...', In reality,  It is unlikely the worst-case scenario will happen.
distortionDetails.reframeExample: Reframe: A mistake, or a judgement from another person is not a reflection on who I am as a person. Most likely, everything is going to be ok.

distortionDetails.name: All-Or-Nothing Thinking
distortionDetails.description: A person with all-or-nothing thinking may believe that they are either perfect or a complete failure. Words like always or never are indicators of all-or-nothing thinking.
distortionDetails.example: Example: I haven't 'made it' yet, so I must be a complete failure.
distortionDetails.reframeExample: Reframe: What evidence do I have that this is completely true? Can I find the nuance, or gray area? Can I focus on progress rather than perfection?.

distortionDetails.name: Emotional Reasoning
distortionDetails.description: A person with emotional reasoning thinks their thoughts reflect reality.
distortionDetails.example: Example: Writing feels hard, so I must be bad at it.
distortionDetails.reframeExample: Reframe: Feelings aren't facts. What evidence do I have that this is completely true? Even though I feel like I am a bad writer, I have gotten positive feedback in the past, and I don't always feel this way. My thought must not be completely true?.

distortionDetails.name: Magnification of the Negative
distortionDetails.description: A person who magnifies the negative will put greater emphasis in possible failures, weaknesses, or threats.
distortionDetails.example: Example: You play a musical performance. You get positive feedback, but also made a few mistakes. You continue to feel embarassed by the mistakes rather than believe the good reviews people gave you.
distortionDetails.reframeExample: Reframe: I only made a few mistakes, and I still got positive reviews. It's possible others didn't even notice the mistakes.

distortionDetails.name: Minimization of the Positive
distortionDetails.description: Putting less emphasis on possible success or opportunity.
distortionDetails.example: Example: You write a short story. You ask a friend for feedback, and they say some nice things. You think,'They are probably just being nice'
distortionDetails.reframeExample: Reframe: I appreciate they took the time to read and compliment my work.

distortionDetails.name: Fortune Telling
distortionDetails.description: Predicting a negative outcome before the event happens, and with insufficient evidence.
distortionDetails.example: Even if I finish this project, It won't turn out how I want it to and no one will like it.
distortionDetails.reframeExample: I won't know how things will turn out until I try. Even if nobody likes my work, I will become a better aritst with practice. You have to make bad art before you can make the good art. I am committed to showing up, and I will try to let go of outcomes.

distortionDetails.name: Mind Reading
distortionDetails.description: Assuming you know what another person is thinking.
distortionDetails.example: Example: My seemed upset today. He must be angry with me.
distortionDetails.reframeExample: Reframe: I can never be sure what is going on in someone else's head. Maybe my boss is stressed about something that has nothing to do with me. If it keeps happening, I can ask him for clarification.

distortionDetails.name: Personalization
distortionDetails.subtitle: It's all my fault.
distortionDetails.description: A person who engages in personalization feels overly responsible for negative outcomes and attributes them to percieved incompetence. They blame themselves entirely.

distortionDetails.name: Other-Blaming
distortionDetails.description: Blaming others holds others responsible for outcomes they may not have had control of, or provides ways for people to overlook their contributions to the issue.

distortionDetails.name: Overgeneralizing
distortionDetails.description: Making a broad conclusion based on one event. A person who overgeneralizes may assume the same result will always occur in the future.
distortionDetails.example: Example: I wasn't a finalist in the competition, so I never will be.
distortionDetails.reframeExample: Reframe: I'll improve with practice, and will be more likely to succeed the more I try.

distortionDetails.name: Labeling
distortionDetails.description: Reducing yourself or another to a single description based on a single event or behavior.
distortionDetails.example: Example: I am a failure for not publishing a book by now. She is a jerk for honking at me in traffic.
distortionDetails.reframeExample: There are a lot of ways to define success, and in a lot of ways I am successful. I have honked in traffic before too. Maybe she was stressed or upset about something else.

distortionDetails.name: Should/Must Statements
distortionDetails.description: Thinking you are obligated to behave or believe a certain way.
distortionDetails.example: I shouldn't feel so angry about this. I should have gotten to work on this project a long time ago.
distortionDetails.reframeExample: Any feeling I am having is a valid feeling. Chastizing myself about how much progress I have made isn't helpful. I am where I am and there are reasons for that. I can only control where I go from here
